name: Artichoke
description: Artichokes are usually grown for the edible flower buds, which are harvested before the flowers open. They need a lot of space, as they will grow into giant bushes.

name: Asparagus
description: Asparagus has been prized by epicures since Roman times. They enjoy fertile, well drained soil free of persistent weeds. They also grow well alongside tomatoes

name: Beet
description: Beets should be a staple of any vegetable garden. As well as being truly delicious, they’re very easy to grow from seed – and you don’t have to wait long ’til harvest time.

name: Bell Peppers
description: Bell Peppers, especially the sweet varieties, are a popular pick to grow in the vegetable garden. They can be challenging to grow in some areas, because they need a good deal of heat and sun to set and ripen their fruits. Pepper plants will sit in the garden and wait for the right conditions before they really start to grow.

name: Broccoli
description: Broccoli is a member of the cabbage family. It is an excellent plant to grow, because not only is it one of the most nutritious of all vegetables, but it is fairly easy to maintain and is not fussy. A cool-season vegetable, broccoli fully matures in only six to eight weeks and then can be cleared away to make room for a late summer or fall crop. In areas where frost comes late, you can plant it again for a fall crop.

name: Cabbage
description: Cabbages are some of the most popular vegetables to grow, although we tend to grow a small fraction of the hundreds of varieties available. ​Cabbage plants can grow in cool weather, so you can get an early start on the season. They can also be re-seeded throughout the summer, to have a continual harvest of heads as you need them rather than having them all mature at the same time.

name: Cantaloupe
description: Sweet, juicy cantaloupe fruit can be yours with the right combination of sun, soil, and —something that's a little hard to control- pollination. Nothing screams summer like an endless bounty of fresh fruit. Colorful and bright, cantaloupe is the perfect addition to an edible garden. This sweet member of the melon family can be grown at home with tender care and a little luck

name: Carrots
description: Growing carrots, or any root vegetable, can be a bit of a gamble since you can't see how well they are doing until you harvest. Even though the roots are growing underground, carrot tops need full sun to light shade for the carrots to grow quickly and develop their sugars.

name: Cauliflower
description: Cauliflower is one of the many cabbage related cole crops that revel in cool weather. Cauliflower is not the easiest vegetable to grow, because it is very sensitive to temperature changes. Cauliflower needs consistent moisture and plenty of it. Without sufficient water, the heads turn bitter.

name: Celery
description: Learning how to grow celery is simple. The main features this crop requires are rich soil, plenty of water, and protection from hot sun and high temperatures. Because a celery plant has such a long maturity time, unless you live in a location with long growing seasons, you need to start celery seeds indoors at least eight to 10 weeks before the last frost date for your area.

name: Courgette
description: Any way you slice it, this healthy powerhouse of squash is all about easy: easy to grow, easy to harvest, easy to use in the kitchen. Zucchini fruit is edible at any stage of maturity, but it tastes best when it's young and tender, long before it balloons into a caveman's club. Growing your zucchini not only gives you access to the fruit at its prime; it also means you can harvest the delicate and delicious yellow flowers of this prolific plant.

name: Cucumber
description: Growing cucumbers will not only produce the freshest, most flavorful cucumbers you can imagine, but they can be very lucrative, too. Within two months, you'll have more cucumbers than you know what to do with! They grow well in container garden settings or in raised beds, just give them a place with maximum sunshine and fertile soil.

name: Eggplant
description: Eggplant is easy to grow and some varieties are so beautiful they can be used as ornamentals. Eggplant is somewhat challenging to grow from seed, but it is worth the effort because there is a huge variety you can buy in seed form, while nurseries often only carry a few varieties.

name: Garlic
description: A close relative of the onion, garlic is an edible, bulbous plant that has been cultivated for several thousand years. For the home gardener, it is quite easy to grow a year's supply, and the leftover crop can be given away to friends and neighbors.

name: Green Beans
description: All kinds of green beans are incredibly easy to grow. You can grow lots of beans in limited space, and there is a huge variety of beans. Green bean plants are either pole varieties that grow long vines or low-growing bush types. For fresh eating, they are picked young and tender before the seeds inside have fully developed.

name: Green Onion
description: Scallions bring the flavor of onions without the long wait in the garden or the peeling in the kitchen. You can even re-root scallions from the grocery store if you leave a couple of inches of stem attached to the roots. You don't even have to plant them in the garden. Scallions will happily grow in a glass of water. When something is this ridiculously easy to grow, you might as well take every opportunity.

name: Kale
description: Kale is a cold-hardy vegetable that can be planted in early spring or autumn. Cool weather brings out the sweet, nutty flavor of this highly nutritious green. It's a superfood! It takes a lot to discourage a kale plant from growing, and they can get by on fewer hours of sunshine than your tomatoes or peppers.

name: Lemon
description: Growing lemon trees in garden pots is a rewarding experience. Not only are they prolific fruit producers, but the blossoms are also incredibly fragrant and beautiful. The lemon fruit is also sweeter than the fruit of other lemons. Even their thin skins are tasty and great for cooking.

name: Lettuce
description: It's a shame that so many people automatically associate flavorless, boring old 'Iceberg' with the word “lettuce.” The world of lettuces is full of color, texture, and flavor. If you grow your own, you have that world at your fingertips. Homegrown lettuce is a delight. You can harvest it whenever you have a craving for a cool, crisp salad, and the combinations of colors and flavors you can enjoy is limited only by your imagination.

name: Potato
description: Potatoes are relatively inexpensive to purchase, but freshly dug potatoes from your home garden have a flavor all their own. Oval baking potatoes and red potatoes have dominated the market, but there are actually over 1,000 different varieties of potatoes available for growing. The starchy tubers grow hidden underground as the top half of the plant matures. The potato can be finicky to grow, because of succeptibility to pests and diseases, and you never really know how they're doing until you harvest. But they are also very rewarding.

name: Pumpkin
description: The plants you know as pumpkins are cultivars of various squash species. They are known for having large fruit with very thick orange or white rinds, which is the feature that makes them so suitable for carving Halloween jack-o'-lanterns. Like most squash species, pumpkins are very easy to grow from seed, but they do require a long growing season and thus are often started from seedlings purchased at a garden center.

name: Radish
description: Radishes are grown in just about every vegetable garden. They are quick to grow and the big seeds are ideal for gardening with kids. When we hear radish, many of us think of small, round, red and tangy. By far, the most popular radishes eaten and grown fit this description, but there are longer varieties and different colored radishes. Small round radishes are such quick and easy growers, they virtually define what a radish should be. Even this humble globe-shaped radish offers a good amount of variety. They can be round or oblong, hot or mild, red, pink, purple, white or bi-colored

name: Raspberry
description: Raspberry bushes are easy to grow and yield an impressive harvest. A few bushes will give you enough fruit to eat, preserve, and share. Berries are a fantastic source of antioxidants, vitamins, and fiber. They’re also delicious. And, when you grow your own you get the perk of being able to harvest at the peak of freshness.

name: Spinach
description: Spinach is a leafy green vegetable that grows best in cool weather. Packed with iron, spinach is even higher in Vitamins A and C, Thiamin, Potassium, and Folic Acid (one of the B-complex vitamins). Like most dark green leafy vegetables, it also contains the carotenoids lutein and zeaxanthin. Spinach also tastes great eaten fresh or cooked.

name: Squash
description: Squash is among the most commonly grown plant in the vegetable garden. The main difference between summer and winter squash is that winter squashes have hard, thick rinds that will help them store for long periods of time. In cooler regions, you can start plants indoors three weeks before the last frost date, but you don't want to start plants any earlier than this because older plants will not always transplant well.

name: Strawberry
description: Garden strawberries are an easy-to-grow fruit that will reward the home gardener with ample harvests for many years. With favorable conditions, each plant should produce one quart of strawberries per season. Garden strawberries produce their fruit in the late spring and early summer months, though it can be earlier in warmer climate zones.

name: Tomatoes
description: Burying your tomato plants deep into the soil helps them grow better because tomatoes form roots all along any buried portion of the stem—if you look closely you will see tiny bumps, which are the roots before they develop! Planting causes the roots to grow stronger, so you may have a more difficult time pulling out the plants at the end of the season. But the healthy, more productive tomato plant will be well worth it!

name: Watermelons
description: Although watermelons aren't difficult to grow, they need a lot of nutrients, sun, warmth, and water to thrive.When you're growing watermelon from seed, plant them in a space that provides plenty of room to roam, as the vines can grow to be up to 20 feet long. To grow to their fullest potential, watermelons need full sun for eight to 10 hours a day.
